scrape.title: The dinner
scrape.author: Carol
scrape.text: THE DINNER raises some strong, heady ideas about love and loyalty, about justice and morality, but it doesn't hammer you over the head with them. Instead, it stabs you in the gut.It begins innocently enough with a dinner at a very exclusive restaurant with two brothers and their wives, and you believe you will be reading a light-hearted novel with sarcastic, funny jabs between brothers and silly descriptions of little morsels of food on vast empty plates, until…….I've read horror novels that aren't as terrifying as this--in its bleakness, in its refusal to give you any room to breathe. Koch has created a marvelously unpredictable narrator, and a black-and-white novel that's full of controversy, humor, irony, and despair. It's not violently graphic by any means, but THE DINNER still comes off as a violent book; it's not for the faint of heart.Brilliant, but heartbreaking in concept.
